While Dax Shepard (writer, actor, co-director) didn't strike pay dirt with this romantic action comedy, he certainly put a smile on my face.  Shepard plays Charlie Bronson (nee Yul Perkins) who is in witness protection in a small northern California town.  He does strike gold, however, when he finds a loving relationship with Annie (real life mate Kristen Bell).  She is a professor at the local college but is about to lose her job due to budget cuts.

Her boss is played by a hilarious Kristin Chenoweth.  Given Annie's doctorate is in nonviolent conflict resolution (admit it, that's funny) her options are limited.  She finds a possible job in Los Angeles, but that means if she drags Charlie along, he will have to leave his protected status.  Of course he does and that's when the Keystone Kops chase begins.

One of his pursuers is an incompetent federal marshal (Tom Arnold) who is also a friend.  Another is Alex (a dreadlocked Bradley Cooper) who was Charlie/Yul's bank robbing partner.  He's accompanied by Yul's former girlfriend played by Joy Bryant who is also Shepard's lover on the TV show "Parenthood."  Then there's an old boyfriend (Michael Rosenbaum) of Annie's.  His gay brother is a county deputy sheriff looking for romance.

Bell and Shepard are great together as they take time to argue about the use of a disparaging word for homosexuals and whether Charlie's hot rod Lincoln Continental is an appropriate vehicle for the couple.  Besides Chenoweth, Cooper steals most of his scenes especially after he confronts Charlie.  Granted some of the jokes fall flat and some of the bits just seem to be added for length.  But overall this is a pleasant, sometimes vulgar road trippin' movie with some terrific stunt driving.

Warning:  You'll want to close your eyes when Charlie and Annie mistakenly walk in on a foursome of septuagenarians au naturale.

I don't usually do movie reviews, but I had a few extra seconds and thought I'd give this one a shot. I remember seeing previews for this, and debated going to see it in theaters, but didn't. I was sorting through Netflix today and saw it on there, remembered it, and thought "Hey, why not". It was actually a decent film. It had a 2 million dollar budget, half of which was spent on music rights, so really the film had a 1 million dollar budget. And for 1 million, the cameras looked great, the cast was much more well known than I was expecting, and overall it was pretty good. Acting obviously didn't win any Oscars, but it was fairly decent. Shepard and Bell, being married in real life, had great chemistry and worked extremely well together. Bradley Cooper, while I love him to death, his character didn't have any real depth and almost seemed like a last minute add on that they decided to write into the story. The car stunts were pretty awesome, and I actually learned that because it was such a low budget film that Dax Shepard did most of his stunt work himself, so props to him for being a great driver.

The only real complaints I have was that the story felt pretty disjointed at times, and didn't feel like the people were making choices that they really would. Maybe they had to trim down some of footage or something? Either way it felt like it was missing a little something.. Like there were lots of random genres that were loosely tied together and while it worked, it felt like they could have done better with it.

Parents: I figure I'll start adding a parents section to those who care or are wondering. One of the things that it's rated R for is "pervasive language", and I didn't really think there was all that much. F bombs were dropped throughout the movie, but only in bursts. Ex: A character at one point runs his car into someone's lawn and onto some of their decorative pieces, and starts cursing and dropping the F word because he's mad. So stuff like that. The only real thing that grossed me out, but also made me laugh, was there are two points where the main characters walk into a motel room with a bunch of old people engaged in... activities. Full frontal male and female nudity it seen, but it is played for comedic effect, so you be the judge there. Really not much violence, probably the worst is a character gets hit in the face and gets a bloody nose, with blood running down his face. Overall not too bad, as the nudity is quick, maybe a 10 second scene each time.

All in all, it's definitely worth a watch once. Would I buy it? If it were in the $5 movie bin, or half off at $7.50. If it gets right down to it, it's got Kristen Bell in it. That in of itself deserves a watch ;)

Hit & Run is a wild ride that never should have worked, but surprisingly it does. The story doesn't appear to be deep or complicated, and just when you think they've come to the end, a whole other angle begins. The film is further helped by a large cast and a whole bunch of interesting cameos, that help take it to another level. Charlie Bronson (Dax Shepard) is happy living in a small town with his girlfriend, Annie (Kristen Bell), but things are about to change. When Annie gets offered a job in L.A., Bronson must decide whether or not to go with her, which also means leaving the safety of the witness protection program. When a jealous ex learns of the plan, he finds out who Charlie really is, and thanks to Facebook, connects with the men he's hiding from, making the trip to L.A. a dash for safety, across California. Dax Shepard is not an actor I find to be very funny, but this was the first time I've seen him play a character as deep as Charlie Bronson, and he was terrific. He is being perused by Bradley Cooper of all people, who I did not see as someone who could play the bad guy. His good looks and charming personality, don't exactly lead one to believe he'd be believable as a bad guy, and while he wasn't the toughest bad guy I've ever seen, he does more than an adequate job. Hit & Run isn't an award winning film, it may not even be all that memorable, but it is extremely entertaining and an edge of your seat thriller ride. The perfect film for those who want to just sit back, relax, and enjoy the show.

I watched Hit & Run on DVD and loved it.  It is a strange story with unusual and interesting characters.  I'm not really into cars but I liked the cars in the movie.  This movie is a self described chase movie which I don't usually watch but this one was interesting and fun.

I decided to buy the movie on Blu Ray because I thought the audio would be even better than on the DVD.  The audio was DTS Master Audio but I was really disappointed.  I thought that on DTS the engines would really roar and even shake my house a bit.  The sound in this movie didn't have the dynamic range I expected and wanted.  It was a missed opportunity by the people making this movie.  The one good thing was that the soundtrack (music) didn't overpower the dialogue because it was just as level as the rest of the audio.

I think that one of the crucial components in making any kind of action or chase movie today is stepping up the game with the audio.  Cars should have a deep throaty roar that shakes the house and can be felt in my chest, breaking glass should have a clear crisp tinkling and sometimes the source of sound should move from speaker to speaker to enhance the motion on the screen.  There should also be a lot of range in volume.  A quiet conversation can be quiet but when the action starts it should be loud enough to add to the excitement.  The soundtrack should be loud enough to add to the excitement and mood of the movie as well but not overpower the dialogue.  This movie at least did that well.

When I watched my first Blu Ray movie the crisp clear video was exactly what I expected.  The uncompressed audio, however, just blew me away.  I was amazed at the audio in the same way I was amazed by the clear video when I first watched a DVD after watching VHS all my life.  I gave this movie three stars because the audio in this movie didn't live up to its potential.  It would have added a lot to the movie if it had.

Note: May contain spoilers. Proceed with caution.

In the world of film it's becoming increasingly apparent that a movie's title can make or break its success. You have the pop culture flicks like Transformers and Fast and Furious, the books-turned-movie franchises like Harry Potter and Twilight, everything else in between, and then you have Hit & Run. At first glance, nothing about the film is appealing: the title, the cover, the fact that Bradley Cooper is sporting dreadlocks. From the gate it already has so much going against it. So why was it so good? How is it possible that this film - which seemed destined to be a train wreck - managed to give me one of the funnest cinematic experiences I've had in months?

Well, to be honest, there's multiple reasons. There's the honest chemistry between the two leads, the carefree script, and the overall fun nature of the film. There was never a point in Hit & Run where I went, "Ok, this is a bit much." In other words, I never felt overwhelmed. You have the action-oriented side of the film and then you have the comedic side. What Dax Shepard did extremely well was find that balance between the two. It never felt like he favored one of these elements over the other and it always felt genuine. Hell, he was even able to throw in a bit of romance and social commentary for good measure. I mean, why not right?

Hit & Run follows the life of Charlie Bronson (Shepard), a man who was put into witness protection four years ago. He's currently living in Milton, California with his girlfriend Annie Bean (Kristen Bell), a professor at a local college. As we all know, you can't leave your area once you're put into witness protection. Unfortunately, Annie recently got offered an interview at the University of California for a job in the field she created herself. While hesitant at first, Charlie decides that she should go and that he would go with her. Things quickly get out of hand as Charlie and Annie are chased by Charlie's supervisor Randy (Tom Arnold), Annie's ex-boyfriend Gil (Michael Rosenbaum), and Charlie's ex-friend Alex (Cooper). All she wanted to do was go to her interview!

What surprised me most was all the social commentary scattered throughout the film. Whether it was society's insensitiveness towards certain words like "f**", how we constantly stereotype people, or our constant impulse to judge someone because of their past instead of looking at who they are now; I mean, they covered it all. What made it better was the fact that it all felt natural. It didn't feel like they threw it in at the last second because they wanted to make the movie seem more appealing to a greater audience. Everything seemed to work perfectly and nothing felt out of place. Major props to Shepard for that.

Also, the on-screen relationship between Charlie and Annie was very well written. While at times I felt Annie was being a bit annoying, especially when she found out the truth about Charlie, I loved that Charlie never got out of hand. He called her out on her being judgmental just like she called him out on being insensitive. Not only that, but the fact that Shepard and Bell are in a relationship in real life translates really well on screen. It helps breathe a certain purity to the characters' relationship which is something you don't see often. They're completely comfortable with each other which allows their relationship to feel authentic.

Finally, the casting in the film is extremely well done. Kristen Bell and Dax Shepard are great together and part of that has to do with their relationship in real life. Then you have Tom Arnold who was a riot in almost every scene he was in. Similarly, Bradley Cooper gave another great performance as Alex. I don't know what it is about him, but he seems to nail every performance he takes on. As the film reaches it's final twenty minutes or so you're greeted with a few familiar faces. Beau Bridges appears as Charlie's dad, Jason Bateman appears as a U.S. Marshal, and Sean Hayes appears as Sandy Osterman, the professor who interviews Annie. It's always nice to see Bateman in a film and I can't even remember the last time I saw Sean Hayes in something.

Overall Score: 8/10 - I must admit that I was not expecting to like this film as much as I did. It's smart, it's funny, and it's a fun ride from start to finish. It's one of those movies that doesn't try to achieve some big goal. It's there to entertain and that's exactly what it did. It does that all while giving you some great social commentary and a nice cast. Overall, Hit & Run is a very well-rounded movie that exceeded my expectations. Definitely recommend you check this out if you have the time.

Dax Shepard writes, stars and co-directs (with David Palmer) in "Hit and Run," a comedy about "Charles Bronson" living in a small town in California, with his girlfriend Annie Bean (Kristen Bell). "Charles Bronson" is shocked to hear that Annie, specializing in nonviolent conflict resolution, has a job interview for a department chair position in Los Angeles. But "Charles Bronson" - of course, this is not his real name - cannot go to Los Angeles, where he left his troubled past four years ago.

Well, in fact the film is nothing serious. Filled with quirky dialogue and eccentric characters, "Hit and Run" is an action comedy that leans towards comedy, or comedy of off-the-wall humor. Made on a budget of $2 million (half of which was reportedly spent to secure music rights), the action scenes of "Hit and Run" are modest at best.

As a comedy, however, this is really a mixed bag. The leading characters are likable, with charming Kristen Bell, but their storyline is predictable and forgettable. The antics are unpredictable and often funny, but random and repetitions. Cars are so cool, and so is the soundtrack music. Oh, and I almost forgot Bradley Cooper. He plays a role that is not very interesting.

"Hit and Run" is a comedy, uneven in tone, with more creative ideas than its generic title suggests, but really in need of a better script.

HIT AND RUN is an odd, but oddly entertaining movie.  Not exactly a comedy.  Not a drama.  Not quite an action film.  I guess it could best be summarized as a comedic action romance.

Dax Shepard plays Charles Bronson (not the movie star), a former bank robbery getaway driver who is currently in witness protection, currently living in small town California.  He's in a strong relationship with a community college teacher (Kristen Bell) and they seem blissfully happy.  Shepard is friendly with his hapless witness protection marshal (Tom Arnold, less annoying than usual), and other than the fact that Shepard doesn't seem to have an action job...all is well.

Things are turned upside down, though, when Bell is a) fired from her current gig and b) given the opportunity to get her dream job at a university in Los Angeles.  Shepard decides he's going to leave his safe environment and follow her to LA...and this triggers a series of unfortunate events culminating in numerous chase scenes, confrontations and misunderstandings.  Eventually, Shepard must confront those whom he betrayed, including his former partner in crime, the Adidas track suit wearing, dreadlocked Bradley Cooper.  Measured chaos ensues.

In some ways, this movie wants to be a breezy action comedy, light and fun.  But the script is also heavily focused on its dialogue, so it feels a little bit like a lightweight Tarantino film, with these scruffy characters being FAR TOO articulate.  Or, perhaps, it feels a little like an action film Woody Allen might have written.  And it tries a bit too hard to make Dax Shepard into a romantic figure.  He speaks poetically to Bell...he's Mr. Sensitive.  And the film was co-directed by Shepard...which to me means he didn't understand that he's not always convincing in this role.  There's no reason he can't be convincing as a romantic...but he's often filmed in dewy-eyed close-up.  He almost teeters into parody.  His character is interesting and unusual, but not always convincing.  I guess if I had to sum it up, it appears that Shepard wanted HIT AND RUN to be the vehicle that turned him into a star...and he misses the mark fairly widely.

Kristen Bell is pleasant enough, but I didn't feel her character was as well rounded.  And the frequent close-ups on her face, unfortunately, revealed the copious amounts of makeup she was wearing.  I mention this because I'm NEVER aware of this sort of thing...but her character is supposed to be "Fresh-faced" and thus, the heavy makeup was a bit jarring.  I admit, this is a really minor quibble...but for some reason, it stood out for me.

Cooper, though an unbelievable character in many ways, is perhaps the most purely amusing character.  He's ridiculous and dangerous.  The conception of his character is over-the-top, yet he downplays it and makes it as "real" as possible.

The movie is peppered with interesting cameos.  Kristen Chenoweth and Sean Hayes come across as bad caricatures.  Jason Bateman appears in a scene for no good reason.  David Koechner pops up.  Beau Bridges actually has a couple of nice moments.

There are chase scenes, but in general, they are not anything special.  (Although good laughs are to be had at the expense of Tom Arnold and the mini-van he drives.)  The scenery is lovely.  There are certainly scattered laughs to be had throughout, and the film was never dull.  But it's just too quirky in an uncontrolled way to really work.  I give it a VERY modest recommendation, because it does have a fair amount of imagination and originality.  But it can't quite shake the "Dax Shepard vanity project" vibe, and thus is less than satisfying.

While Dax Shepard (writer, actor, co-director) didn't strike pay dirt with this romantic action comedy, he certainly put a smile on my face. Shepard plays Charlie Bronson (nee Yul Perkins) who is in witness protection in a small northern California town. He does strike gold, however, when he finds a loving relationship with Annie (real life mate Kristen Bell).

She is a professor at the local college but is about to lose her job due to budget cuts. Her boss is played by a hilarious Kristin Chenoweth. Given Annie's doctorate is in nonviolent conflict resolution (admit it, that's funny) her options are limited. She finds a possible job in Los Angeles, but that means if she drags Charlie along, he will have to leave his protected status. Of course he does and that's when the Keystone Kops chase begins.

One of his pursuers is an incompetent federal marshal (Tom Arnold) who is also a friend. Another is Alex (a dreadlocked Bradley Cooper) who was Charlie/Yul's bank robbing partner. He's accompanied by Yul's former girlfriend played by Joy Bryant who also is Shepard's lover on the TV show "Parenthood." Then there's an old boyfriend (Michael Rosenbaum) of Annie's. His gay brother is a county deputy sheriff looking for romance.

Bell and Shepard are great together as they take time to argue about the use of slang term for gays and whether Charlie's hot rod Lincoln Continental is an appropriate vehicle for the couple. Besides Chenoweth, Cooper steals most of his scenes especially after he confronts Charlie. Granted some of the jokes fall flat and some of the bits just seem to be added for length but overall this is a pleasant, sometimes vulgar road trippin' movie with some terrific stunt driving.

Billed as an action film - and it certainly has that element - it's at its core a touchy-feely romance comedy, with a very sweet, pro-human attitude. If you can, watch the first two minutes; if you like them, you'll like the movie as a whole. I'm in line for whatever Dax Shepard writes next.

Charles (Dax Shepard), not his real name, is in the Witness Protection Program (WPP) in the sleepy little town of Milton. Randy (Tom Arnold) who is a fallen from grace, inept federal marshal is assigned to watch over him. Annie (Kristen Bell) is Charles' girlfriend. She knows he is in the Program, but not the details. Gil (Michael Rosenbaum) is Annie's ex-bf who is still in love with her.

When Annie gets offered a job in LA, Charles insists she go take it, and he opts to drive her himself in his 700 HP "suicide doors" Lincoln. They are chased by Gil, Randy, Gil's brother Terry (Jess Rowland) who is a gay policeman, and bad guy Alex (Bradley Cooper), the reason why Charles is in the WPP to begin with.

The film turns into "Smokey and the Bandit" with gun fire. The unorthodox relationship of the two stars is the heart of the film. Annie is an expert in solving non-violent conflict solutions and Charles is...well let's say he is trying.

The second half of the film digresses. I won't say it falls off a cliff, but it could have been done better in this romantic action/comedy.

Parental Guide: F-bombs, some really ugly nudity, male nudity.

Charlie is in a Witness Protection program, after he ratted out his gang members, who are all bank-robbers. His location is in California as he tries to keep a low profile. But then, he meets Annie, who is a professor and on the verge of losing her job. Charlie falls in love with Annie, and he follows her to L.A., where she seeks a new job. The drama begins as Charlie steps out of his Protective boundary,and all hell breaks loose as the chase begins. A former friend, also a marshal, and a member of his bank-robber gang go after Charlie at full-speed. Most of the scenes are very funny, and some laugh-out-loud entertainment, combined with romance. Superb acting performance, and just enough action. A great summer movie to enjoy. Highly recommended to all comedy lovers!

Have you ever watched a movie in which all the characters sounded a little too erudite? Everyone in this goofy thing sounds as though he or she is a college-educated sociologist with a bit of new-age jargon thrown in. It was nice to hear, but I had to wonder if that was the intention of screenwriter Dax Shepard ("Brother's Justice") or if he lacks the skill to write more varied and authentic dialogue.

This is a high-octane road race between a wide variety of muscle cars, custom-built race cars and one sturdy SUV, all because a former getaway driver (for bank robbers) who is in the Witness Protection Program, has promised to drive his sweetheart to a job interview 600 miles away, and nothing, not her ex-boyfriend, not his former gang members, not his dad, not a U.S. Marshall, nor his girlfriend's change of heart, can stop him.

We see:
  * Kristen Bell ("Big Miracle") specializes in conflict resolution. She has a great job opportunity IF she can get to her Los Angeles interview in time. She thinks her boyfriend witnessed a crime.
  * Dax Shepard ("When in Rome") admitted to his girlfriend he was in the Witness Protection Program, but he failed to mention that he was an accomplice in those crimes.
  * Bradley Cooper ("Limitless") spent some painful time in jail because our hero ratted him out. Now he's mad! (But he loves dogs and doesn't want to see them fed inferior dog food.)
  * Joy Bryant ("Welcome Home, Roscoe Jenkins"), our hero's former girlfriend, is part of that bank-robbing gang, AND she's a pretty fair shot!
  * Beau Bridges ("The Descendants") is our hero's father. The two of them used to race custom-built cars.
  * Tom Arnold ("Madea's Witness Protection") is the U.S. Marshall determined to protect his witness. This character could give the U.S. Marshall Service a bad name!
  * John Duff ("The Game Plan") is the body builder in the clichd tank top who buys cheap dog food for his pit bull.

In this R-rated comedy, expect constant profanity, some nudity, no blowie uppie stuff, a few gunshots and a LOT of vehicular mayhem. Expect a couple of surprise cameos at the end...and watch your Amazon.com DVD all the way through the credits.
